prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The primary objective of the observations is to observe CO(3-2) emission from these PG QSO hosts. We configured the observations using the 1875 MHz bandwidth spectral setup in dual polarization mode. The CO(3-2) line is placed in the LSB, and the HCO+(4-3) line is placed in the USB. The additional bandwidth is for the detection of continuum emission. While the HCO+ and the continuum emission may not be detected, these data can be obtained at no cost to the primary objective of the proposal.
The resolution of 0.2" corresponds to 200 pc at a z~0.05. This will be sufficient to determine if the CO emission is nucleated or extended.

The primary objective of the observations is to observe CO(3-2) emission from these PG QSO hosts. PG1119+120 is the faintest source in the sample. That, combined with the location of the observed frequency of the CO(3-2) makes this source the most difficult to detect (given our assumptions about the extent of the emission). The emission may be more compact or clumpy than our conservative estimate, but the assumption for the sensivity calculation is that we will detect the CO(3-2) with a signal-to-noise ~ 7, but will not have velocity information (i.e., the calculation is done over the whole CO line width).
The CO(1-0) flux is 2.7 Jy km/s. In Papadoupoulos et al. (2008), we obtained single-dish CO(3-2) measurement of PG 1119+120. The measured flux is S_CO(3-2)Dv = 21 Jy km/s. For a line with of 217 km/s, the peak S_CO(3-2) is 96 mJy. We require a spatial resolution of 0.2" to measure the compactness/extent of the CO emission. If a resolution channel of ~ 50 km/s is adopted and the source is assumed to be unresolved, it will take only a few minutes to achieve a signal-to-noise, S/N, ~ 10 per channel in the line. If instead we adopt the conservative estimate that the CO is extended over an area equivalent to a diameter of 1.5" (= 56 beams) and set the bandwidth to 217 km/s, it will take on the order of 2.3 hours to achieve a S/N ~ 7. This is a very conservative estimate - the emission is likely to be clumpy. Note also that the single-dish observations of PG 1119+120 will provide a check of whether of not any emission is resolved out in the ALMA observations.
While the CO(3-2) is the focus of the proposal, the possible detection of the continuum emission would allow additional analysis to be accomplished. For the continuum, we estimate a 850 m continuum emission flux density of 1.8 mJy. This is based on its measured f100m flux density of ~ 750 mJy, and the assumption that the host has the same f850m / f100m flux density ratio (= 0.0024) as the warm, ultraluminous Seyfert 1 galaxy Mrk 231. This estimate may be on the low-side; the warm infrared galaxies NGC 4418 and NGC 7469 have f850m / f100m ~ 0.0055-0.0085. Given the estimated continuum flux of 1.8 mJy, it will be detected at the 50 sigma level in 2.2 hours if the continuum emission is unresolved, but will not be detectable (0.8 sigma) if it is extended over an area equivalent to a diameter of 1.5". NOTE again that the detections of the 850m continuum emission and the HCO+(4-3) emission line ARE NOT REQUIRED to achieve our primary science goal, but it does provide additional science if detections are made.

The primary objective of the observations is to observe CO(3-2) emission from these PG QSO hosts. For PG1244+026, the velocity bandwidth has been selected to allow 4 resolution elements across the entire CO line. In the case where the CO emission is compact or clumpier than our conservative estimate, we will be able to do our kinematic analysis using a higher velocity resolution.
The CO(1-0) flux is 3.0 Jy km/s. In Papadoupoulos et al. (2008), we obtained single-dish CO(3-2) measurements of a sample of PG QSO hosts. A flux ratio in the range of CO(3-2)/CO(1-0) ~ 5 - 10 was measured for three PG QSO hosts, which an average value of 8. For PG1244+026, we have estimated the peak CO(3-2) flux density based on this average ratio to be 192 mJy. We require a spatial resolution of 0.2 to best measure the compactness/extent of the CO emission. If a resolution channel of ~ 30 km/s is adopted and the source is assumed to be unresolved, it will take only a few minutes to achieve a signal-to-noise, S/N, ~ 100 per channel in the line. If instead we adopt the conservative estimate that the CO is extended over an area equivalent to a diameter of 1.5 (= 56 beams), it will take ~ 2.0 hours to achieve a S/N ~ 7. This is a very conservative estimate - the emission is likely to be clumpy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our CO(1-0) survey of z < 0.3 UV-excess PG QSO hosts has shown that at least 38% reside in CO-rich host galaxies. We propose 0.1"-0.2" resolution ALMA Band 7 observations of CO(3-2) emission from four PG QSO hosts previously detected in CO(1-0). This sample has been selected to be nearby (z < 0.2), have a declination < 15 degrees, and to have CO(3-2) redshifted to a frequency with good atmospheric transmission. The CO(3-2) line is an ideal diagnostic line for star formation; it traces the dense, warm molecular gas component associated with high mass star-forming regions in galaxies. With these data, we will (a) measure the compactness of the CO(3-2) emission and its distribution relative to stellar light, (b) determine if the radio emission from these QSOs is co-spatial with the CO(3-2), and thus associated with star formation, and (c) make use of the CO(3-2)-IR luminosities relation of starburst galaxies to estimate the host star formation rates. This survey turns the focus of our extensive QSO work over the past few decades directly to diagnosing their starburst properties.
